questions.question: What is the maximum state and local tax (SALT) deduction for itemizers under TCJA (2018-2025)?
questions.explanation: TCJA limits the SALT deduction to $10,000 ($5,000 for married filing separately). This includes state/local income or sales taxes plus property taxes combined.
questions.tip: SALT cap: $10,000 ($5K MFS). Includes income/sales + property taxes combined.

questions.question: A sole proprietor has $100,000 net profit from Schedule C. What is the self-employment tax?
questions.explanation: SE tax applies to 92.35% of net earnings. SE tax = $100,000 × 92.35% × 15.3% = $92,350 × 15.3% = $14,130 (rounded). The 92.35% factor simulates the employer's half of FICA.
questions.tip: SE tax: 92.35% of net profit × 15.3% (12.4% SS + 2.9% Medicare).

questions.question: A donor with $10,000 basis and $25,000 FMV gifts property. No gift tax is paid. What is the donee's basis for gain purposes?
questions.explanation: For gifts of appreciated property, the donee takes carryover basis (donor's basis) for gain purposes. The donee's basis is $10,000. FMV at gift is used only to determine loss basis if FMV is below donor's basis.
questions.tip: Gift basis (appreciated property): Carryover donor's basis. Holding period tacks on.

questions.question: What is the maximum employer contribution to a SEP IRA as a percentage of compensation?
questions.explanation: SEP contributions are limited to 25% of compensation (W-2 wages) or 20% of net self-employment income (after SE tax deduction adjustment). The dollar cap is $69,000 for 2024.
questions.tip: SEP: 25% of W-2 wages or ~20% of SE income. Max $69,000 for 2024.

questions.question: Which type of income qualifies for the earned income credit?
questions.explanation: EIC is based on earned income: wages, salaries, tips, and net self-employment income. Investment income disqualifies the credit if it exceeds the threshold. Passive income doesn't qualify.
questions.tip: EIC = earned income only. Investment income threshold disqualifies if exceeded.

questions.question: If the first spouse to die uses only $5 million of their $13.61 million estate exemption, what can the surviving spouse use under portability?

options.B: Their exemption plus the deceased spouse's unused exclusion (DSUE)

questions.explanation: Portability allows the surviving spouse to use their own exemption plus the DSUE (deceased spouse's unused exclusion). If $5M was used, DSUE = $8.61M. Surviving spouse can use $13.61M + $8.61M = $22.22M total.
questions.tip: Portability: Surviving spouse gets DSUE. Requires timely estate return for first death.

questions.question: An S corporation shareholder lends $50,000 directly to the corporation. How does this affect loss deduction capacity?

options.B: Creates debt basis allowing additional loss deduction

questions.explanation: Direct shareholder loans to an S corporation create debt basis, which allows loss deductions after stock basis is exhausted. Debt basis is restored before stock basis when income flows through.
questions.tip: S corp debt basis: Direct loans only. Bank loans TO corp don't create shareholder basis.

questions.question: A partner with $30,000 basis receives a $40,000 cash distribution. What is the tax consequence?
questions.explanation: Cash distributions exceeding basis trigger capital gain (not ordinary income). Gain = $40,000 - $30,000 = $10,000 capital gain. The partner's basis is reduced to zero.
questions.tip: Partnership cash distribution > basis = capital gain. Property distributions generally no gain.

questions.question: A taxpayer purchased an annuity for $100,000 and will receive $10,000 annually for 15 years. What is the annual exclusion ratio?
questions.explanation: Exclusion ratio = Investment / Expected return = $100,000 / $150,000 (15 × $10,000) = 66.7%. Each payment is 66.7% tax-free return of capital and 33.3% taxable interest.
questions.tip: Annuity exclusion ratio: Investment ÷ expected return. Applies until basis recovered.

questions.question: A 15-year-old dependent has $5,000 of unearned income in 2024. How much is subject to kiddie tax?
questions.explanation: Kiddie tax applies to unearned income exceeding $2,500 (2024). First $1,300 is tax-free (standard deduction), next $1,300 at child's rate, excess at parent's rate. Subject to kiddie tax: $5,000 - $2,300 = $2,700.
questions.tip: Kiddie tax: Unearned income > $2,500 (2024) taxed at parent's rate.

questions.question: An activity is presumed to be a business (not a hobby) if it produces a profit in how many of the last 5 years?
questions.explanation: The safe harbor presumes business (not hobby) status if profitable in 3 of the last 5 years (2 of 7 for horse breeding/racing). This is rebuttable—all facts and circumstances are considered.
questions.tip: Hobby presumption: 3 of 5 years profitable = presumed business. IRS can still challenge.

questions.question: A corporation has an NOL in 2024. Under current law, the NOL can offset what percentage of taxable income in future years?
questions.explanation: Post-2017 NOLs can offset 80% of taxable income in carryforward years (indefinite carryforward, no carryback for most NOLs). Pre-2018 NOLs had different rules (2-year back, 20-year forward, 100% offset).
questions.tip: Post-2017 NOL: 80% of taxable income, indefinite carryforward, no carryback.

questions.question: A taxpayer donates publicly traded stock (held 3 years, basis $10,000, FMV $50,000) to a public charity. What is the deduction and AGI limitation?
questions.explanation: Long-term capital gain property donated to public charities is deductible at FMV ($50,000) subject to a 30% of AGI limit. The taxpayer can elect to reduce the deduction to basis and use the 60% limit instead.
questions.tip: Appreciated LTCG property to public charity: FMV deduction at 30% limit. Election for basis at 60%.

questions.question: Which factor most strongly indicates independent contractor (rather than employee) status?

options.B: Worker controls how and when work is performed

questions.explanation: Control over how, when, and where work is performed is the key factor. Independent contractors control their methods; employers control employee work. Other factors: financial investment, opportunity for profit/loss, relationship permanence.
questions.tip: Worker classification: Control is key. Behavioral, financial, and relationship factors all matter.

questions.question: After South Dakota v. Wayfair, states can require sales tax collection based on:

options.B: Economic nexus (sales volume or transaction count)

questions.explanation: Wayfair (2018) overruled physical presence requirement. States can now require sales tax collection based on economic nexus thresholds (typically $100,000 sales or 200 transactions in the state).
questions.tip: Wayfair: Economic nexus for sales tax. Physical presence no longer required.

questions.question: A taxpayer sells stock with a $20,000 loss to their sibling. What is the tax consequence?

options.B: Loss is disallowed; sibling gets no basis adjustment
options.C: Loss is disallowed; sibling can use it to reduce gain on subsequent sale
options.D: Loss is suspended until sibling sells

questions.explanation: Section 267 disallows losses on sales to related parties. However, if the related party subsequently sells at a gain, the previously disallowed loss can offset that gain (but not create or increase a loss).
questions.tip: Section 267 loss: Disallowed to seller. Related buyer can use to reduce later gain, not losses.

questions.question: A taxpayer has $94,000 in traditional IRA (all pre-tax) and makes a $6,000 nondeductible contribution, then converts $6,000 to Roth. How much is taxable?
questions.explanation: Pro-rata rule applies: Nondeductible portion = $6,000 / $100,000 total = 6%. Taxable portion of $6,000 conversion = 94% × $6,000 = $5,640. Cannot cherry-pick only nondeductible amounts.
questions.tip: Backdoor Roth: Pro-rata rule. All IRAs aggregated. Consider emptying traditional IRA first.

questions.question: Trusts and estates reach the highest marginal tax bracket (37%) at approximately what income level for 2024?
questions.explanation: Trusts and estates have highly compressed brackets. The 37% rate begins at approximately $14,450 (2024) compared to $609,350 for single individuals. This creates incentive to distribute income to lower-bracket beneficiaries.
questions.tip: Trust brackets: 37% at ~$14K. Very compressed. Plan distributions to beneficiaries.

questions.question: A taxpayer with $20,000 annual itemized deductions and a $29,200 standard deduction (MFJ 2024) should consider:
questions.explanation: Bunching concentrates deductible expenses (especially charitable contributions) into alternate years to exceed the standard deduction in 'bunching' years while taking standard deduction in off years. Maximizes total deductions over time.
questions.tip: Bunching: Concentrate deductions to exceed standard deduction some years. Maximizes benefit.

questions.question: Capital gains invested in a qualified opportunity fund must be invested within how many days of the sale generating the gain?
questions.explanation: QOZ investments must be made within 180 days of the sale or exchange generating the gain. The 180-day period can start later for pass-through entity gains (from entity's year-end or return due date).
questions.tip: QOZ investment: 180 days from gain realization. Pass-throughs have extended start dates.

questions.question: Employer-provided health insurance premiums are:

options.B: Excluded from employee income and deductible by employer

questions.explanation: Health insurance is a tax-advantaged fringe benefit. Premiums are excluded from employee income (including FICA) and deductible by the employer. This makes employer health coverage very tax-efficient.
questions.tip: Employer health insurance: Excluded from employee income, deductible by employer. Triple tax benefit.

questions.question: If a grantor dies during the GRAT term, what happens to the trust assets?

options.A: Assets pass to remainder beneficiaries free of estate tax
options.B: A portion of assets is included in the grantor's estate
options.C: All assets are included in the grantor's estate
options.D: Assets revert to a charitable organization

questions.explanation: If the grantor dies during the GRAT term, Section 2036 includes the portion of trust necessary to produce the remaining annuity payments (using the Section 7520 rate at death). This is the mortality risk of GRATs.
questions.tip: GRAT mortality risk: Die during term = inclusion for remaining annuity value.

questions.question: A business has $2 million gross receipts, including $180,000 from SSTB activities. Is the entire business treated as an SSTB?

options.A: Yes—any SSTB income taints the whole business
options.B: No—SSTB portion is below the 10% de minimis threshold
options.C: No—SSTB rules only apply to service businesses

questions.explanation: The de minimis rule: If gross receipts ≤$25M, SSTB activities must exceed 10% to taint the business. If >$25M, threshold is 5%. Here: $180,000 / $2,000,000 = 9%, below 10%, so business is NOT an SSTB.
questions.tip: SSTB de minimis: <10% (under $25M) or <5% (over $25M) SSTB receipts = not tainted.

questions.question: A U.S. corporation pays dividends to a UK resident shareholder. Without a treaty, the withholding rate is 30%. Under the U.S.-UK treaty, the rate may be reduced to:

options.D: Both A and B depending on ownership

questions.explanation: Tax treaties typically reduce withholding on dividends. The U.S.-UK treaty provides 5% for substantial shareholders (10%+ ownership) and 15% for portfolio investors. Treaties require Form W-8BEN to claim reduced rates.
questions.tip: Treaty withholding: Typically 5% (substantial) or 15% (portfolio). Claim via W-8BEN.

questions.question: Once activities are grouped for passive activity purposes, can they be regrouped?

options.A: Yes—taxpayer can regroup freely each year
options.C: Yes—but only with a material change in facts and circumstances

questions.explanation: Grouping elections are generally binding once made, but regrouping is allowed if facts and circumstances materially change (such as ownership or management changes). Consistency is required absent material change.
questions.tip: Passive activity grouping: Generally irrevocable. Regrouping only for material changes.

questions.question: For stock to qualify as QSBS under Section 1202, the issuing corporation must have aggregate gross assets not exceeding:
questions.explanation: QSBS requires the C corporation to have aggregate gross assets of $50 million or less at issuance and immediately after the stock is issued. The stock must be acquired at original issuance and held for 5+ years for full exclusion.
questions.tip: QSBS: $50M gross asset limit, C corp, original issuance, 5-year hold for 100% exclusion.

questions.question: In a Type A reorganization, a shareholder receives stock worth $80,000 and cash of $20,000. The shareholder's basis in the old stock was $50,000. What is the recognized gain?
questions.explanation: Realized gain = $100,000 received - $50,000 basis = $50,000. Boot triggers gain recognition, but limited to the lesser of boot or realized gain. Boot = $20,000; realized gain = $50,000. Recognized gain = $20,000.
questions.tip: Reorganization boot: Gain recognized = lesser of boot received or realized gain.

questions.question: A partner receives $100,000 cash in complete liquidation of their partnership interest. Their outside basis is $120,000. What is the tax result?
questions.explanation: In a liquidating distribution, gain is recognized only if cash exceeds basis. If cash is less than basis (and only cash is received), a capital loss is recognized. Loss = $100,000 - $120,000 = $20,000 capital loss.
questions.tip: Partnership liquidation: Cash < basis = capital loss (if only money/751 property received).

questions.question: A taxpayer transfers an existing life insurance policy to an ILIT. When are the death proceeds excluded from the insured's estate?
questions.explanation: The 3-year rule (Section 2035) requires transfers of life insurance to an ILIT to survive 3 years for estate exclusion. If the insured dies within 3 years, proceeds are included in the estate. New policies purchased by the ILIT avoid this rule.
questions.tip: ILIT 3-year rule: Transfer existing policy → survive 3 years. New policy in ILIT avoids this.

questions.question: A deferred compensation plan violates Section 409A. What are the tax consequences to the employee?

options.B: Income inclusion plus 20% penalty plus interest

questions.explanation: Section 409A violations result in: (1) immediate income inclusion of all vested deferred compensation, (2) 20% additional tax penalty, and (3) premium interest from the date of deferral. Very severe consequences.
questions.tip: 409A violation: Income + 20% penalty + interest. Extremely punitive—ensure compliance.

questions.question: An S corporation with accumulated E&P has passive investment income exceeding 25% of gross receipts. What are the consequences?

options.B: Corporate-level tax on excess passive income
options.D: Both B, and termination if excessive passive income continues for 3 consecutive years

questions.explanation: S corps with E&P and >25% passive income face: (1) corporate tax on excess net passive income, and (2) termination of S status if this continues for 3 consecutive years. Solution: distribute E&P or reduce passive income.
questions.tip: S corp passive income: >25% with E&P = tax + possible termination after 3 years.

questions.question: A charitable remainder trust sells highly appreciated stock for $1 million gain. When is the gain taxed?

options.D: To income beneficiaries as distributions are made (tier system)

questions.explanation: CRTs are tax-exempt, so no immediate tax on the gain. The gain is distributed to income beneficiaries under the four-tier system as distributions are made: ordinary income first, then capital gains, then other income, then corpus.
questions.tip: CRT: Tax-exempt entity. Gain taxed to beneficiaries via four-tier distribution system over time.

questions.question: An individual U.S. shareholder of a CFC has a GILTI inclusion of $100,000. What is the effective tax rate without a Section 962 election (assume 37% bracket)?
questions.explanation: Individual CFC shareholders pay ordinary income rates on GILTI without the Section 250 deduction (which is available only to C corporations). At the 37% bracket, the effective rate is 37%. Section 962 election can reduce this.
questions.tip: GILTI for individuals: Full ordinary rates without Section 962. Consider Section 962 election.

questions.question: A taxpayer owns an LLC that rents property to their S corporation (where they materially participate). The rental LLC generates $50,000 income and the taxpayer has $30,000 passive losses from other activities. What is the result?

options.B: Self-rental income is nonpassive; $30,000 passive loss suspended
options.C: All income and losses are passive

questions.explanation: Self-rental income (rental to a business where taxpayer materially participates) is recharacterized as nonpassive. The $50,000 cannot absorb other passive losses. The $30,000 passive loss remains suspended.
questions.tip: Self-rental rule: Income from property rented to your active business = nonpassive.

questions.question: Which strategy can reduce or eliminate net investment income tax exposure?

options.A: Converting passive investments to active businesses with material participation

questions.explanation: NIIT applies to net investment income (passive income, capital gains, dividends, interest). Converting passive activities to active (material participation) removes them from NII. Real estate professionals with material participation can exclude rental income from NIIT.
questions.tip: NIIT planning: Convert to active business, qualify as REP, manage MAGI below thresholds.
